title: Is it worth buying a model of Apple iMac that has been discontinued by Apple? - Quora
tags: Advice About Apple Products and Services

response.answer_text: Depends on which models you’re talking about.† Anything pre-2011. Really not at all. They can’t run the latest OS and their hardware is so outdated. What’s more, the 2009–2010 models had some really stark hardware flaws that are very expensive to fix. They were hard to recommend when they were new, much less 8–12 years later. 2011 is a maybe. It was one of the best models of iMacs ever (along with the whole Mac line in 2011) and made for great, lower cost Macs to start out with when they hit the used market after a few years. In addition to some great processors and other features, they also came with Thunderbolt which allowed for some great expandability, including the ability to add USB 3.0 and USB C, but also the ability to add an external graphics card. These were great machines. Unfortunately, they have finally lost support for macOS and are not able to run the current version of macOS 10.14 Mojave. With an SSD and increased memory and installation of macOS 10.13 High Sierra, they still make for great machines (I’m typing this answer on a 2011 iMac right now), but we’re reaching a point of diminishing returns with them. 2012-present models for sure. These are all great models with current software support and many of them had the options of SSDs. It can be hard to install your own SSD, but with Thunderbolt you can expand almost endlessly. Obviously, this is predicated on getting a good price. I recently purchased a 2013 iMac for under $300 (they typically sell for upwards of $1000) because it was dropped and the bottom is dented and the screen is cracked. It works for my purposes. †This answer was written October of 2018 and can be assumed to be up to date to that time.

Do you mean something like a 2016 or 2017 Apple iMac still in its box—something that’s “new” (meaning unused), although it’s an older or discontinued model? If it’s a matter of affordability, I wouldn’t hesitate. If you’re buying a used machine that’s older than a year or two, I’d have it checked out first. And if a tech-savvy person gives it a clean bill of health, I’d go for it. Heck, I’m using a 2009 MacBook Pro. It’s ready to receive its last rites—I’ve had to replace the keyboard, remove the battery and disconnect the trackpad—and often goes dark without warning. I suspect that’s because it has been subject to rough handling, bouncing along in an unpadded backpack stashed in the trunk of my car in fifty thousand-plus miles of road trips over its lifetime. The fact that this MacBook works at all is a testament to its fundamental robustness and superior design. I’ve had issues with it, of course. It’s running Mac OS X 10.8.4, which browsers like Google Chrome and Firefox no longer support. Apple’s own non-serious software applications like Pages can’t be opened. But that’s OK as long as I have BBEdit, my text-editing software of choice. It’s different with an Apple iMac. The iMac is a desktop, so chances are good that even if it’s a used machine, it hasn’t been subjected to much abuse. Besides, it’s a workhorse—built to last.
